Q. An argument that assumes the truth of what it is trying to prove.
Q. An argument that appeals to popular opinion as the basis for its truth.
Q. An interruption between the initial idea and the conclusion.
Q. An argument based on a personal attack on someone's character.
Q. When a source is viewed negatively because of its connection with another person or group.
Q. Substituting a person's actual position with a misrepresented (and usually weaker) version of their argument.
Q. The conclusions that one thing caused another simply because one happened before the other.
Q. An argument that wrongly assumes there are only two possible positions.
Q. Drawing a conclusion based on a small sample size; a broad claim based on limited evidence.
Q. An argument that misleads or distracts from a relevant or important issue.
Q. The belief or suggestion that something natural is always better than unnatural.

Q. 1. Occurs when an argument which is supposed to prove something concludes something else instead
Q. 2. Occurs when an arguments contradict one another
Q. 3. Any argument of the form: If A is true then B is true; If A is not true then B is not true.
Q. 4. Any argument of the form: If A is true then B is true; if A is not true then B is not true
Q. 5. Occurs when the element of pity is used instead of logical reasoning is used to argue
Q. 6. Occurs when an argument is considered to be valid because it is what the majority thinks
Q. 7. Occurs when someone tries to refute an argument by attacking the character of a person instead of attacking the ideas of the argument
Q. 8. Occurs when two or more points are rolled into one and the reader is expected to accept or reject both at the same time, when one point may be satisfactory while the other is not
Q. 9. Occurs when the direction between cause and effect is reversed
Q. 10. Occurs when a sample is not significant enough to support a generalization about population
Q. 11. Occurs when a series of increasingly superficial and unacceptable consequences is drawn
Q. 12. Occurs when the position of the opposition is twisted so that it is easier to refute
Q. 13. Occurs when the argument quotes an expert who's not qualified in the particular subject matter
Q. 14. The authority in question is mentioned or named
Q. 15. Occurs when something is instantly concluded to be true just because it is proven to be false, and vice versa

Q. Supports a claim with the claim itself
Q. The use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
Q. Unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit
Q. Assumption that because two things happened together, one caused the other
Q. Presents only two choices when more options exist
Q. A very broad claim based on very little evidence
Q. A misrepresentation of an opponent’s position that makes it easier to argue against

Q. Would the following paragraph be positive bias or negative bias?
Recently, studies show that kids are stressed out when they come home from school and have loads of homework. Between after school sports, activities, and family time, students are finding less and less time to complete homework. Every parent wants to see their child succeed when it comes to school, so why not help your child out? As long as you aren’t giving too much assistance, helping with homework can be a good thing. Set up a homework time every night with your child, provide support, and monitor his or her work. It’s important that your child knows they can count on you they are stuck.

Q. Would the following paragraph be positive bias or negative bias?
Expensive. Obesity. Addictive.Three words that show that video games can be bad for you. Sometimes video games can cost $40-$50 a piece! That’s a lot of money when you think of how many video games you own. Video games can be addicting, leaving little time to spend with family and friends…and little time to go outside and get some exercise. Which leads to obesity. If people are choosing to stay indoors to play video games, they are not getting outdoors and participating in outside activities. We must put an end to the amount of time spent on gaming!

Logical Fallacy Types: to inform readers about different kinds of waves
sentence:
Q. A wave is any movement that carries energy. Some waves carry energy through water. Others carry energy through gases, like air, or solid materials. If you drop a rock into a pool of water, a wave, or ripple of energy, skims across the pool's surface. In the same way, an underwater earthquake can release energy into ocean water. Then it carries a giant wave, or tsunami, across the surface until it hits land. If you hear a clap of thunder, sound waves (or vibrations) have carried the crashing BOOM to your ears. Sound waves speed through the air at about 1,100 feet (335 meters) per second. Light also travels through the air in waves. They travel at more than 186,000 miles (300 million meters) per second. So the light waves from a flash of lightning reach your eyes before that clap of thunder reaches your ears! Electrons travel in waves, too. They move back and forth in a solid wire, sending waves of electricity so you can turn on a light during the storm!

Logical Fallacy Types: Rosa Parks was an important person of the 20th century. She refused to give up her seat on a bus, which led to a boycott of the bus system. She earned many honors for her work in the civil rights movement
sentence:
Q. Rosa Parks has been called the "mother of the civil rights movement." She is one of the most important people of the 20th century. In December of 1955, she refused to give up her seat on a city bus to a white passenger. The bus driver had her arrested. She was sent to court. She was found guilty of breaking the law.
Her act sparked a boycott of the bus system by blacks. Blacks refused to use the buses for more than a year. The boycott introduced the country to a man named Martin Luther King, Jr. People all over the country came to know King. Soon, the U.S. Supreme Court made segregation on city buses against the law.
Over the next forty years, Rosa Parks helped make Americans aware of the history of the civil rights struggle. She earned many honors, including the Martin Luther King Jr. Nonviolent Peace Prize. She is an example of courage and strength. She inspires all Americans to live free.

Logical Fallacy Types: When you mis-represent someone's argument, making it easier to attack.
sentence: Q. What's the straw-man fallacy?

Logical Fallacy Types: Assuming that if action A happens, it will snowball to outcome Z (which might be outrageous).
sentence: Q. What is the slippery slope fallacy?

Logical Fallacy Types: When you "move the goalposts" or act like you (or someone special to you) shouldn't have to follow the same rules as everyone else.
sentence: Q. What is special pleading?

Logical Fallacy Types: When you believe that independent events are somehow related (I've lost this game 10 times; statistically I have to win soon!)
sentence: Q. The gambler's fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you present two options as the only possible alternatives, when more alternatives actually exist.
sentence: Q. The black or white fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: Presuming that one thing is the cause of another thing, even if it isn't true.
sentence: Q. The false cause fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you attack your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.
sentence: Q. Ad hominem is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you ask a question that has an assumption built into it so you can't answer it without appearing guilty.
sentence: Q. A loaded question is...

Logical Fallacy Types: Appealing to popularity, or the fact that many people do something (regardless of whether it's right).
sentence: Q. Bandwagon is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you make a circular argument where the conclusion is included in the premise.
sentence: Q. Begging the question is...

Logical Fallacy Types: Saying that because someone in power over you believes something, it must be true.
sentence: Q. Appeal to authority is...

Logical Fallacy Types: Suggesting that because something is "natural" it is valid, justified, and right.
sentence: Q. When you appeal to nature, you are...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you assume that what's true for one person/thing should be true for all people/things.
sentence: Q. The composition/division fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you use personal experience or one isolated incident instead of a valid argument, especially to dismiss statistics.
sentence: Q. An anecdotal fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you manipulate your audience's emotions instead of using a valid argument.
sentence: Q. Appeal to emotion is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you avoid criticism by turning it back on the accuser.
sentence: Q. Tu quoque is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you say you don't have to prove you are right, it's your opponent's job to prove you wrong.
sentence: Q. Burden of proof is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you suggest no one of a specific race, ethnicity, cultural group would think/say/believe this thing as a way to dismiss an argument.
sentence: Q. No true Scotsman is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you choose specific clusters of data that support your argument, or make a data pattern to fit your argument.
sentence: Q. The Texas sharpshooter fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you assume a claim is wrong because someone committed a fallacy while trying to prove it.
sentence: Q. The fallacy fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you say that something is difficult to understand, therefore it must be false.
sentence: Q. Personal incredulity is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you use double meanings or unclear language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.
sentence: Q. The ambiguity fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you judge something good or bad on the basis of someone's background.
sentence: Q. The genetic fallacy is...

Logical Fallacy Types: When you say a compromise or middle point between two extremes must be the truth.
sentence: Q. The middle ground fallacy is...

Q. JOHN F. KENNEDY: I'm not satisfied when the United States had last year the lowest rate of economic growth of any major industrialized society in the world… (from opening statement)
RICHARD NIXON: We heard tonight, for example, the statement made that our growth in national product last year was the lowest of any industrial nation in the world. Now last year, of course, was 1958. That happened to be a recession year. But when we look at the growth of G.N.P. this year, a year of recovery, we find that it's six and nine-tenths per cent and one of the highest in the world today… (from opening statement)
September 26, 1960
Chicago, Illinois

What logical fallacy does Kennedy use?

Q. MARVIN STONE: You suggest that we scrap the SALT II treaty already negotiated, and intensify the build-up of American power to induce the Soviets to sign a new treaty - one more favorable to us. President Carter, on the other hand, says he will again try to convince a reluctant Congress to ratify the present treaty on the grounds it's the best we can hope to get. Now, both of you cannot be right. Will you tell us why you think you are?
RONALD REAGAN: Yes. I think I'm right because I believe that we must have a consistent foreign policy, a strong America, and a strong economy. And then, as we build up our national security, to restore our margin of safety, we at the same time try to restrain the Soviet build-up, which has been going forward at a rapid pace, and for quite some time.
October 28, 1980
Cleveland, Ohio
What logical fallacy did Reagan’s response illustrate the use of?

October 11, 1992
St. Louis, Missouri

Logical Fallacy Types: false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together, one caused the other
sentence: Q. Last year, the city of Brookfield allocated more money to public parks. This year, however, littering increased, so the increase in park funding must have been responsible.

Logical Fallacy Types: hasty generalization: a very broad claim based on very little evidence
sentence: Q. On my walk to work this morning, a woman on her bike nearly ran me off the sidewalk. I hadn't realized that cyclists were so aggressive and rude!

Logical Fallacy Types: appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good
sentence: Q. Christina's shoes are superior, because they're made from one hundred percent snakeskin, not synthetic materials.

Logical Fallacy Types: ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent
sentence: Q. Thanks to her enduring popularity with employees, Annie Smith is the best-liked CEO in our company's history.

Logical Fallacy Types: guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something
sentence: Q. Don't try to tell me that you only watch educational programming, Emmy! I know for a fact that your sister only watches reality television.

Logical Fallacy Types: appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good
sentence: Q. This herbal supplement is made from a plant that grows in Zambia. It must be healthier than taking that medication, which is full of chemicals I can't pronounce.

Logical Fallacy Types: ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent
sentence: Q. Officer, I was only driving as fast as everyone around me. I'm sure I wasn't speeding.

Logical Fallacy Types: guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something
sentence: Q. Did you really vote for Donald as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?

Logical Fallacy Types: false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together, one caused the other
sentence: Q. Since Lucy Sutton became vice president of the parent-teacher association, student performance has declined and teacher morale is down. We on the school board believe that Sutton bears sole responsibility for the downtrend.

Logical Fallacy Types: false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
sentence: Q. If Mom didn't turn off the air conditioner, then clearly she must be too hot.

Logical Fallacy Types: Ad hominem: an attack against the person making the argument rather than the argument itself.
sentence: Q. Before I refute my opponent's argument, I would like to draw attention to the fact that he is sweating and clearly does not have much experience on the debate team.

Logical Fallacy Types: Slippery slope fallacy: the false assumption that a small first step will lead to extreme consequences.
sentence: Q. Don't let your children stay up till midnight on New Year's Eve. Before you know it, they'll be demanding to stay up till midnight every night.

Logical Fallacy Types: Hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations
sentence: Q. Two of my best friends are really introverted, shy people, and they both have cats. That leads to me believe that most cat lovers are really shy.

Logical Fallacy Types: Strawman: a misrepresentation of an opponent’s position that makes it easier to argue against
sentence: Q. The mayor argued that we need to reduce funding for the animal shelter in order to balance the budget. Don't vote for someone who doesn't think the government should care about animals.

Logical Fallacy Types: Hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations
sentence: Q. I've only read a couple pages of this book, and I've already found a typo. There's no way I'm reading the rest of this garbage.

Logical Fallacy Types: Circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
sentence: Q. Senator Randall isn't lying when she says she cares about her constituents—she wouldn't lie to people she cares about.

Logical Fallacy Types: Strawman: a misrepresentation of an opponent’s position that makes it easier to argue against
sentence: Q. Ms. Long has suggested that our schools let students take statistics instead of algebra to graduate. Frankly, it is puzzling to me that she thinks algebra is a useless subject.

Logical Fallacy Types: Circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
sentence: Q. Free speech is good not just for the individual, but for all of society. After all, it's in the interest of the community that everyone should be at liberty to express his or her beliefs.

Logical Fallacy Types: Circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
sentence: Q. Companies that make huge profits must be exploiting their customers because the only way a company could make large profits is by taking advantage of their customers.

Logical Fallacy Types: Bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct

Q. The following is an example of what fallacy?
Attacking a defendant's character rather than addressing the actual facts of the alleged criminal activity - "You haven't held a steady job since 1992. Worse than that, we couldn't find a single employer who'd provide you with a good reference."

Everyone is going to get the new smart phone when it comes out this weekend. Why aren’t you?

Christine has a terrible experience with a boyfriend. She decides that all boys are mean.

Everyone in our family has gone to the University of Tennessee, so you need to apply to UT.

Caroline says that she thinks her friends should not be so rude to the new girl. Jenna says that she cannot believe that Caroline is choosing to be better friends with the new girl than the girls who have always known her.

Every time I go to sleep, the sun goes down. Therefore, my going to sleep causes the sun to set.

Logical Fallacy Types: Circular Argument - The “evidence” just restates the claim.
sentence: Q. 1. “iPhones are the best smartphones on the market because Apple makes the best smartphones.”

Logical Fallacy Types: Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc - It assumes that what happened 2nd is an effect of what happened 1st.
sentence: Q. 1. “Michael Jordan wore his UNC shorts during every game he played in the NBA and he won 6 championships.”

Logical Fallacy Types: False Dilemma - It pretends there are only two choices and ignores other possibilities.
sentence: Q. ”You can start a family early, or build financial stability for a better family life in the future.”

Logical Fallacy Types: Bandwagon - It appeals to popularity as proof.
sentence: Q. FOMO

Logical Fallacy Types: Straw Man - It makes another version of the argument and attacks that instead of the real argument.
sentence:
Q. A: “Many stores are telling their employees to say Happy Holidays instead of Merry Christmas.”

B: “This is crazy! Why are they trying to get rid of Christmas?!”
Q. “If we let teenagers wear whatever they want to school, they will no longer respect the rules and academic performance will decline.”
Q. “Because young male drivers are twice as likely to get into a car accident, they should pay more for car insurance.”
Q. “The economy has improved greatly because of the new president.”
Q. “I know that what I experience is real because I can see, hear, smell, touch and taste everything.”
Q. “Eat great food at our restaurant, or eat sad, boring meals at home.”
Q. “This is how most schools evaluate their students, so it must be effective.”

Q. A: “We need to move towards self-driving cars as the next step in greater road safety.”

B: “But what about the self-driving Uber that didn’t stop and killed a pedestrian in Arizona?”

Q. Attacking your opponent's character or personal traits in an attempt to undermine their argument.

Q. Making what could be called an appeal to purity as a way to dismiss relevant criticisms or flaws of an argument.
Q. Manipulating an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
Q. Assuming that what's true about one part of something has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it.
Q. Believing that "runs" occur to statistically independent phenomena such as roulette wheel spins.
Q. A circular argument in which the conclusion is included in the premise.
Q. Where two alternative states are presented as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist.
Q. Saying that a compromise between two extremes is necessarily the truth.
Q. Using the opinion or position of an authority figure, or institution of authority, in place of an actual argument.

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the claim is rejected because of the person making the claim, not the claim itself.
sentence: Q. Ad Hominem

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the complexities of a problem are ignored and issues are made simpler than they should be.
sentence: Q. Oversimplification

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the claim assumes something that still needs to be proven. Thus, the claim and the evidence are the same.
sentence: Q. Circular Reasoning/Begging the Question

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which an irrelevant topic is presented in order to divert attention from the original issue.
sentence: Q. Red Herring

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the issue is presented as black and white with no gray areas. Either it is ___, or ___, and nothing in between.
sentence: Q. Either/Or; False Dilemma

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the first of two events is presented as the cause of the second event, when in fact, the effect may have an entirely different cause.
sentence: Q. Cause-and-Effect

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the audience is encouraged to believe in something because “everyone else” believes in it or  that only the “elite” share the opinion presented.
sentence: Q. Bandwagon/Snob Appeal

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the writer/speaker makes sweeping statements about a situation, and may invoke stereotypes, or preconceived impressions about people, places, or things.
sentence: Q. Overgeneralization and Stereotype

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which audience is lead to a conclusion that is not supported by the evidence.
sentence: Q. Faulty Reasoning

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which a premise is established that contracts another, earlier premise.
sentence: Q. Contradictory Premises/Logical Paradox

Logical Fallacy Types: A defect that weakens an argument.
sentence: Q. Logical Fallacy

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which assumptions are made about a whole group or range of cases based on a sample that is inadequate (usually because it is atypical or just too small). Stereotypes are a common type.
sentence: Q. Hasty Generalization:

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which a claim is made that a sort of chain reaction, usually ending in some dire consequence, will take place, but there's really not enough evidence for that assumption.
sentence: Q. Slippery Slope

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which an opponent’s argument is oversimplified and distorted to create a trivial, easy-to-refute argument, which is then “knocked down” by the arguer.
sentence: Q. Straw Man

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the arguer tries to get people to accept a conclusion by making them feel sorry for someone.
sentence: Q. Appeal to Pity

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which it is implied that because there is no conclusive evidence on an issue, the arguer’s position should be accepted.
sentence: Q. Appeal to Ignorance

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy that relies on comparisons to prove a point rather than arguing inductively (logical steps leading to a conclusion) and deductively (a conclusion that can be broken into logical steps).
sentence: Q. Faulty Analogy

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy that appeals to an improper authority, such as a famous person or a source that may not be reliable, but rather, attempts to capitalize upon feelings of respect or familiarity with a famous individual.
sentence: Q. Appeal to Authority, or “Improper” Authority

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy in which the argument represents only one side of an issue, thus distorting the issue.
sentence: Q. Stacking the Deck/Stacked Evidence

Logical Fallacy Types: A logical fallacy that uses force, the threat of force, or something other unpleasant backlash to make the audience accept a conclusion.
sentence: Q. Appeal to Force
